VOL. XXXII, No. 8

SEVENTY-FIVE AT
LACROSSE PRACTICE
Fifty Rookies and Twenty-five
Vets Turn Out
ROBINSON TO BE COACH
Fall Practice Necessary for
New Men—Van Orman
Fall lacrosse practice got under
way yesterday with its usual vigor
as Father Bill Schmeisser, Norman
Robinson and George Helfrich gave
the fifty rookies who reported for
duty a light work-out "on the wall."
Coach Schmeisser was well pleased
With the large number of candidates,
and although as yet he has discovered no luminaries, he feels sure that
he will be able to add some badly
needed reserve strength to the squad
as the season progresses, without
lowering the high caliber of last
Year's small squad.
Stickwork Essential

After a few words on the importance of developing proficient stickwork and the large part the old
concrete wall has played in turning
out championship Hopkins lacrosse
teams, the new men started limbering up under the direction of Robinson and Helfrich, who will act as
coaches to train the new material.
Equipment was given out to the
men who reported for practice, and
it was announced the practice would
be held from 4 o'clock until dark
oil Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays until the Christmas recess, and
longer if the weather permits.
Fourteen "H" Men
Fourteen of the -sixteen "H" men
Will be back in harness again this
Year, and a fifteenth, Robinson, will
be back as coach. Maxwell Cone,
veteran in-home, is the only letter
man who will not be back in the
ranks this year.
Bill Logan, the clever in-home,
who could not be stopped; Tom
Biddison, All-American, "the man
who changed lacrosse tactics ;" Don
Sharretts, husky second string
home; George Helfrich, star of two
Years, who will probably fill Robinson's position, and Grigsby Farinholt will certainly give opposing
goal tenders plenty of cause for
worry.
Midfield Strong

For the midfield positions, there
are Kelsa
Morrill, Larkin Farm.holt, John Lang, Benny Boynton
and Frank Dotterweich ; Hersperger, Nixdorf and Covell will be right
behind them
plenty of practice—and to offer
competition.
The old defense line still remains
Im pregnable. Roy, Mallonee and
Captain Leibensperger make it so
With the small but clever Ray Finn
blocking the way to the net.
Reserves Needed

With last year's first and second
string teams practically intact, the
outlook for the Jays certainly is a
bright one. The large number of
candidates will undoubtedly
supply
Plenty of reserve strength so that
the Jay
coaches will not be faced
with the same problem
that caused
them so much worry during
the

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 28, 1927

TWO DANCES AFTER
TOMORROW'S GAME
Following out its new program, the Athletic Association
will hold a tea dance tomorrow
afternoon after the football
game with Delaware, and a
regular evening dance Saturday night from 9 until 12.
Both dances will be held in the
Civil Engineering Hall, and
music will be furnished by the
Blue Jay Orchestra. Admission for the tea dance will be
fifty cents, and one dollar for
the dance in the evening.

YES AND NO

PRINTERS OF

You wouldn't dare accuse an eminent psychologist of good
salesmanship, would you? You wouldn't insinuate that there
might be a better English composition text than "Writing," or
a better French composition than that of Shanks and Meras ?
Would you suggest that so distinguished a scholar as the exdirector of the Play Shop, who supplements his income with the
rent from several boarding-houses, is dependent on the royalties
of a modest grammar? And can you believe that the history
of Europe has ever been better chronicled than here? You
wouldn't, couldn't and can't, huh? Well, you're entitled to your
opinion. However, even if Drs. Latane, Turner, Dunlop, Shanks,
French and Mr. Uhler do tacitly insist on the superiority of these
their works, why must the more intelligent' men necessarily consume more of printers' ink and of my money than their more
modest confreres? There is an inconsistency. The names of
Latane and Dunlop, I am told, have occasionally been murmured
elsewhere than at Hopkins; they need not write at all, yet they
write five times as much as either Dr. French or Mr. Uhler, who
are—well, modest.

The younger generation is again conspicuous by virtue of
"Dusty Answer," first novel of a young English girl, Rosemond
Lehmann. One's parents, as a general rule, dislike it, which is
probably sufficient reason for enthusiasm. The unfortunate reality is that none of us are as clever or as intense as the figures of
the novel; conversation, among the young people of the day, is
a lost art, and very enthusiastic living never goes hand in hand
with intelligence, as Miss Lehmann would have us believe. No
sensible person could decry a lack of le joie de vivie at Hopkins,
nor would it be kind to insinuate that individual undergraduates
are unintelligent, but for the ideal combination one is indubitably
driven to the Cane Club or the R. 0. T. C.

A WORD ABOUT THE HONOR SYSTEM
An extremely interesting article which appeared in the. October
number of Tyler's Historical and Genealogical Magazine delves
into the origin and early history of the Honor System in American colleges. After tracing its growth at William and Mary
College and at the University of Virginia, the article goes on to
deplore the fact that with the introduction of the system into
the larger colleges, the attempt to enforce the Honor System
have caused it to lose many of the connotations which originally
adhered to it. The article concludes by saying: "Honor may
attend this new system, but it is not an essential part of it. Under
it the student may be likened to a cog in a machine, and it may
be more truly termed 'A Student Machine System' than 'A Student
Honor System'."
This explanation hits the nail on the head. The sole reason
why the Honor System has succeeded so phenomenally at Johns
Hopkins, while it has had to be abandoned at so many other
colleges, is that here the enforcement of the system's implications
is actually left to the honor of the individual students, and to their
honor alone. The Honor System at this college is.an Honor System in all the fullness of the term. Each student (and we may
safely say that there are very few exceptions) feels the personal
incumbency to fall in line with the one genuine tradition which
this University cherishes. The same idea that inspired the birth
of the system at William and Mary in 1779 keeps it alive at Johns
Hopkins in 1927.

One may safely say that there was never such a football game
as the recent scuffle between Hopkins and Loyola. The brand of
football, I am told by connoisseurs, did not compare with that
seen in the Stadium on the previous Saturday, but who cares for
good football, anyway? Perhaps, from the players' point of view,
a more satisfactory victory would have resulted from playing
consistently dull to the onlookers; if any method other than passing had been of the slightest avail, the team would have been gratified, Dr. Van Orman mollified and the spectators stupefied. And
what a note on which to close! No sensible plugging in midfield,
no quick tackle, jumble of bodies and a whistle-flash; but a long
pass, a neat swoop, a heart-breaking run, an impossible tackle
and, above all, a cap-pistol!

THE REPORT OF THE JUNE WEEK COMMITTEE
The 1927 June Week Committee deserves credit on several
scores. It not only submitted an exhaustive constructive report
to the 1928 committee, but it had the rare moral fiber to publish
the fact that it sustained a deficit. It is the custom here at Hopkins for deficits to be forgotten. It is not salutary to "spirit,"
it is said, for students to know that any of their activities are not
financial bonanzas.
In addition to its display of courage, the 1927 committee epitomized its experiences for the benefit of future June Weeks.
Instead of floundering around with inaccurate guesses, the 1928
committee and its successors will have a definite, tangible basis
upon which to work. Thomas McNeal and J. Albert Abraham,
chairman and treasurer, respectively, of the 1927 committee, have
rendered a valuable service. On behalf of the student body, the
NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity to extend its thanks to these
men.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS

Activities Council
Fills Vacancies
At the initial meeting of the year
of the Student Activities Council,
Tuesday, elections were held to fill
the several existing vacancies.
Richard H. Wood will represent the
Black and Blue Jay in the place of
James Levi; Norman Gardiner will
take the post of Thompson for the
Debating Council, and Douglas
Prahl that of Bolton for the Barnstormers.
A motion was also passed that the
$2,000 surplus of the 1926-27 Hullabaloo be awarded to the 1927-28
year book, provided that permission
of the respective managets be obtained.
In the absence of McElfresh,
president of the Council, who is ill,
Osmar Steinwald presided.

When a certain fraternity on the
campus of Boston University recently desired to_lease a private
dwelling, they ran up against an
line-riveted difficulty. The owner
of the house demanded that cc, substantial bond be posted as a security
against possible damage of an exPensive chandelier in the diningroom. The owner explained that he
had to canvass several insurance
companies before
he could find one
Who would stake their money
against the traditional exuberance
and rough-house tendencies of college men. This company, however,
Would not consider the risk without
an extremely high premium rate.

believes the American college students are just as moral as they ever
Were. This statement provoked a
good bit of adverse comment from
the student body of the University
of Chicago. It would appear that
these students are jealous of the
reputation they have been enjoying,
and are loath to lose it.

Entrants
DR. ELLIOTT LEADER
Petting and Social Difficulties
Discussed
Johns Hopkins took a prominent
part in the Council of Christian
Associations Conference held at the
University of Delaware last week.
Lowell S. Ensor and E. A. Schaal
were members of the conference
committee. Huber Klemme was
pianist. Miss Emily Austin, Hopkins' only "co-ed" delegate, and
Lowell S. Ensor led the singing of
the conference.
Six From Hopkins

But slow progress is being made
in the Fall Tennis Tournament, and
as things stand now it looks as
though the Fall Tournament might
be finished in time to aid in. picking
the Varsity Tennis Squad next
spring.
Approximately forty men were
paired off in the tournament and
four rounds, semi-finals and finals
were arranged to take care of all
the competitors. A ladder bracket
was arranged to take care of the
pairings-off and all preparations
were made for a rush to the tennis
courts.
To date there are seven matches
yet to be played in the first round,
ten more in the second round, and
only two players have advanced as
far as the third grouping. These
play-offs came as the result of the
first week of competition, and further progress has been at a standstill
ever since.

SEVENTY-FIVE AT
LACROSSE PRACTICE
Fifty Rookies and Twenty-five
Vets Turn Out
ROBINSON TO BE COACH
Fall Practice Necessary for
New Men—Van Orman
Fall lacrosse practice got under
way yesterday with its usual vigor
as Father Bill Schmeisser, Norman
Robinson and George Helfrich gave
the fifty rookies who reported for
duty a light work-out "on the wall."
Coach Schmeisser was well pleased
With the large number of candidates,
and although as yet he has discovered no luminaries, he feels sure that
he will be able to add some badly
needed reserve strength to the squad
as the season progresses, without
lowering the high caliber of last
Year's small squad.
Stickwork Essential

After a few words on the importance of developing proficient stickwork and the large part the old
concrete wall has played in turning
out championship Hopkins lacrosse
teams, the new men started limbering up under the direction of Robinson and Helfrich, who will act as
coaches to train the new material.
Equipment was given out to the
men who reported for practice, and
it was announced the practice would
be held from 4 o'clock until dark
oil Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays until the Christmas recess, and
longer if the weather permits.
Fourteen "H" Men
Fourteen of the -sixteen "H" men
Will be back in harness again this
Year, and a fifteenth, Robinson, will
be back as coach. Maxwell Cone,
veteran in-home, is the only letter
man who will not be back in the
ranks this year.
Bill Logan, the clever in-home,
who could not be stopped; Tom
Biddison, All-American, "the man
who changed lacrosse tactics ;" Don
Sharretts, husky second string
home; George Helfrich, star of two
Years, who will probably fill Robinson's position, and Grigsby Farinholt will certainly give opposing
goal tenders plenty of cause for
worry.
Midfield Strong

For the midfield positions, there
are Kelsa
Morrill, Larkin Farm.holt, John Lang, Benny Boynton
and Frank Dotterweich ; Hersperger, Nixdorf and Covell will be right
behind them
plenty of practice—and to offer
competition.
The old defense line still remains
Im pregnable. Roy, Mallonee and
Captain Leibensperger make it so
With the small but clever Ray Finn
blocking the way to the net.
Reserves Needed

With last year's first and second
string teams practically intact, the
outlook for the Jays certainly is a
bright one. The large number of
candidates will undoubtedly
supply
Plenty of reserve strength so that
the Jay
coaches will not be faced
with the same problem
that caused
them so much worry during

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 28, 1927

TWO DANCES AFTER
TOMORROW'S GAME
Following out its new program, the Athletic Association
will hold a tea dance tomorrow
afternoon after the football
game with Delaware, and a
regular evening dance Saturday night from 9 until 12.
Both dances will be held in the
Civil Engineering Hall, and
music will be furnished by the
Blue Jay Orchestra. Admission for the tea dance will be
fifty cents, and one dollar for
the dance in the evening.

YES AND NO

PRINTERS OF

You wouldn't dare accuse an eminent psychologist of good
salesmanship, would you? You wouldn't insinuate that there
might be a better English composition text than "Writing," or
a better French composition than that of Shanks and Meras ?
Would you suggest that so distinguished a scholar as the exdirector of the Play Shop, who supplements his income with the
rent from several boarding-houses, is dependent on the royalties
of a modest grammar? And can you believe that the history
of Europe has ever been better chronicled than here? You
wouldn't, couldn't and can't, huh? Well, you're entitled to your
opinion. However, even if Drs. Latane, Turner, Dunlop, Shanks,
French and Mr. Uhler do tacitly insist on the superiority of these
their works, why must the more intelligent' men necessarily consume more of printers' ink and of my money than their more
modest confreres? There is an inconsistency. The names of
Latane and Dunlop, I am told, have occasionally been murmured
elsewhere than at Hopkins; they need not write at all, yet they
write five times as much as either Dr. French or Mr. Uhler, who
are—well, modest.

The younger generation is again conspicuous by virtue of
"Dusty Answer," first novel of a young English girl, Rosemond
Lehmann. One's parents, as a general rule, dislike it, which is
probably sufficient reason for enthusiasm. The unfortunate reality is that none of us are as clever or as intense as the figures of
the novel; conversation, among the young people of the day, is
a lost art, and very enthusiastic living never goes hand in hand
with intelligence, as Miss Lehmann would have us believe. No
sensible person could decry a lack of le joie de vivie at Hopkins,
nor would it be kind to insinuate that individual undergraduates
are unintelligent, but for the ideal combination one is indubitably
driven to the Cane Club or the R. 0. T. C.

A WORD ABOUT THE HONOR SYSTEM
An extremely interesting article which appeared in the. October
number of Tyler's Historical and Genealogical Magazine delves
into the origin and early history of the Honor System in American colleges. After tracing its growth at William and Mary
College and at the University of Virginia, the article goes on to
deplore the fact that with the introduction of the system into
the larger colleges, the attempt to enforce the Honor System
have caused it to lose many of the connotations which originally
adhered to it. The article concludes by saying: "Honor may
attend this new system, but it is not an essential part of it. Under
it the student may be likened to a cog in a machine, and it may
be more truly termed 'A Student Machine System' than 'A Student
Honor System'."
This explanation hits the nail on the head. The sole reason
why the Honor System has succeeded so phenomenally at Johns
Hopkins, while it has had to be abandoned at so many other
colleges, is that here the enforcement of the system's implications
is actually left to the honor of the individual students, and to their
honor alone. The Honor System at this college is.an Honor System in all the fullness of the term. Each student (and we may
safely say that there are very few exceptions) feels the personal
incumbency to fall in line with the one genuine tradition which
this University cherishes. The same idea that inspired the birth
of the system at William and Mary in 1779 keeps it alive at Johns
Hopkins in 1927.

One may safely say that there was never such a football game
as the recent scuffle between Hopkins and Loyola. The brand of
football, I am told by connoisseurs, did not compare with that
seen in the Stadium on the previous Saturday, but who cares for
good football, anyway? Perhaps, from the players' point of view,
a more satisfactory victory would have resulted from playing
consistently dull to the onlookers; if any method other than passing had been of the slightest avail, the team would have been gratified, Dr. Van Orman mollified and the spectators stupefied. And
what a note on which to close! No sensible plugging in midfield,
no quick tackle, jumble of bodies and a whistle-flash; but a long
pass, a neat swoop, a heart-breaking run, an impossible tackle
and, above all, a cap-pistol!

THE REPORT OF THE JUNE WEEK COMMITTEE
The 1927 June Week Committee deserves credit on several
scores. It not only submitted an exhaustive constructive report
to the 1928 committee, but it had the rare moral fiber to publish
the fact that it sustained a deficit. It is the custom here at Hopkins for deficits to be forgotten. It is not salutary to "spirit,"
it is said, for students to know that any of their activities are not
financial bonanzas.
In addition to its display of courage, the 1927 committee epitomized its experiences for the benefit of future June Weeks.
Instead of floundering around with inaccurate guesses, the 1928
committee and its successors will have a definite, tangible basis
upon which to work. Thomas McNeal and J. Albert Abraham,
chairman and treasurer, respectively, of the 1927 committee, have
rendered a valuable service. On behalf of the student body, the
NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity to extend its thanks to these
men.

INTERCOLLEGIATE

Activities Council
Fills Vacancies
At the initial meeting of the year
of the Student Activities Council,
Tuesday, elections were held to fill
the several existing vacancies.
Richard H. Wood will represent the
Black and Blue Jay in the place of
James Levi; Norman Gardiner will
take the post of Thompson for the
Debating Council, and Douglas
Prahl that of Bolton for the Barnstormers.
A motion was also passed that the
$2,000 surplus of the 1926-27 Hullabaloo be awarded to the 1927-28
year book, provided that permission
of the respective managets be obtained.
In the absence of McElfresh,
president of the Council, who is ill,
Osmar Steinwald presided.

VO

Only Two Men Have Completed
Hopkins Delegates Prominent
Matches So Far—Forty
at Delaware Meeting.
Entrants
DR. ELLIOTT LEADER
Petting and Social Difficulties
Discussed
Johns Hopkins took a prominent
part in the Council of Christian
Associations Conference held at the
University of Delaware last week.
Lowell S. Ensor and E. A. Schaal
were members of the conference
committee. Huber Klemme was
pianist. Miss Emily Austin, Hopkins' only "co-ed" delegate, and
Lowell S. Ensor led the singing of
the conference.
Six From Hopkins

But slow progress is being made
in the Fall Tennis Tournament, and
as things stand now it looks as
though the Fall Tournament might
be finished in time to aid in. picking
the Varsity Tennis Squad next
spring.
Approximately forty men were
paired off in the tournament and
four rounds, semi-finals and finals
were arranged to take care of all
the competitors. A ladder bracket
was arranged to take care of the
pairings-off and all preparations
were made for a rush to the tennis
courts.
To date there are seven matches
yet to be played in the first round,
ten more in the second round, and
only two players have advanced as
far as the third grouping. These
play-offs came as the result of the
first week of competition, and further progress has been at a standstill
ever since.
